Pioneer Experiences: A General Questionnaire

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual could be asked exactly the same questions as another. Some of the questions will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If you have sheets of paper, if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, just initiate to give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be either very young or old, and personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives has a questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadians Eat?" It is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Edmonton, Sask.

Pioneer Experiences: A General Questionnaire

Saskatchewan Archives No. 2

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual was asked to enumerate all his experiences. It has usually been necessary to ask questions which may prove impossible to answer. If there is not sufficient space to answer the question, just write "not applicable" or "not applicable" or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1934, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives has prepared a list of other questionnaires which may be useful to you. If you have already answered these, and are willing to do so, please put a check mark next to each one that applies to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Enclosure of Questionnaire

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Before I left, they came to me before I had made my decision.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

With my wife and her husband.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Rail to Winnipeg, boat to Halifax (summer season), rail to British Head.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We took two more weeks, and I lost in the heavy of the land and strength from weakness. By the time we got there, we were out of the woods, which was a good thing. We were very weak, but we were able to get through.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We landed at Regina, then moved to North Battleford, and finally settled in Saskatoon.

16. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Working on the family farm in Victoria until I came to Canada. We had a hard time adjusting to the new environment.

Rail to Winnipeg, boat to Halifax (Steamer Aurora), sail to St. John's, N.B.

14. What hardships of the journey must do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, rivers, mountains, or other obstacles)

We lost one man, overboard, and I fell in the river of foamy water.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

With Mr. Thomas Johnson, former resident of Kitchener, Kansas, then, for a couple of weeks until we moved my little house place a bit more backwoods - it was a big shack with no floor except dirt floor, and I then moved there would have a lot with my wife, but he came with us and his family, and they lived there for many years, and then moved back.

16. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How about you came?

Working on the growing farm in Nebraska until came to Canada. While had three acres of land, came myself back in Canada, but could not persuade my wife to come back. Worked there at that farm work, office work, and coal mining. During the four years until my last interview, I worked with horses also both outside work as I had been used to work, and now employed by my new employer, and I am employed at present for $1.25 a day. Bought my own horse for $125 and work back for $1.25.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

Yes, my brother Peter and his family came in 1907. My friend John Smith came in 1905.

24. Will you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

Yes, we traveled quite a bit. We went to church every Sunday and visited our friends and family regularly.

I don't think I have anything of value in this respect, but I find anything I will send it on.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Son, Frank, married with 3 children, farming my old farm here — Joseph with travel and mechanical training, working at home; Florence and Jane going to school.

Son, Jack, married with 4 children, with Edmonton Motors at Edmonton Alta — Kenneth married, with 1 child, with Edmonton/Henderson, Edmonton — Evelyn Helen 2 years old — Bertha with Woodworths Dry Dept., Vancouver — Keith in the Air Force, Edmonton and Jack at school, Edmonton.

Daughter, Mary Gordon, married (now Mrs. Golly) 1 son, going to school — They are farming west of Raymond.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Probably not the most important, but perhaps the most easily seen and having a most important, fresh in other improvements, are the improvements in transportation and communication. When I stood on the platform at Indian Head and looked down the track of the C.P.R. on March 19th, it looked like a wire fence blown down compared to the tracks I had left in England. Now we have tracks on all sides of us capable of carrying 180 car loads. In place of the rutted roads, we now have good gravelled roads, with many of them gravelled and black top coming nearer to our suburbs. Buses and motor cars make it possible to reach centres in a fraction of the time necessary in the warm and buggy days of the 1870's. Telephones have cut the isolation of the early days but still in some ways we seem to lack the human intimacy of the early days. Education has made great strides since the little red school house defended for its life on the injuries of war in a small district. His assistance of support today has made a great improvement, but I wonder that field must be widened until it includes the nation.
